Correcting for accounting miscategorizations of operating and capital expense is not nitpicking It has consequences for both valuation and pricing altering your perspective on companies and changing your valuation amp pricing judgments

When a capital expense is miscategorized as an operating expense still standard accounting practice you will skew operating amp net income down at most firms and take your biggest asset off the balance sheet amp out of book equity

When a financing expense like leases is miscategorized as an operating expense standard accounting practice until 2019 operating income and debt at firms will be understated affecting operating margins amp ROIC

In Accounting 101 expenses are categorized into operating capital and financing expenses and the categorization determines where these expenses show up in the financial statements and what those statements tell us about the business

Fair enough I think you are taking my disagreement with ESG as a concept with disagreement about wanting to make the world a better place We all want the latter I just dont see a pathway where ESG gets us there In fact I see lots of pathways where it makes it worse

There is no light at the end of the ESG tunnel If you work in the space your choices are to be a useful idiot toiling in the trenches for what you think is a good cause be a feckless knave in it just for the money or find something else to do

ESG utopians believe that the problem with ESG is that it is mismeasured and misused However ESG mismeasurement is endemic greenwashing is an ESG feature not an ESG bug and underperformance is what you should expect in steady state for ESG funds

ESG expansionists argue that the solution is to bring in Russialike risks into ESG scores but expanding ESG to include missed risks after every crisis and political risks specifically will make a bloated measure even more so

Just as a thought experiment if China invaded Taiwan do you think firms would be abandoning Chinese operations fund managers selling Chinese holdings and individuals giving up all things Chinese as easily as they gave up Russian vodka I dont

Some ESG advocates point to the corporate amp investor pull out from Russia after Ukraine as evidence of better behavior but it is easy to be moral when you are giving up a tiny slice of revenues and those operations are no longer economically viable

Leading into the Russia crisis ESG services were missing Russia in their ESG scores ESGdriven companies persisted with Russia investments and ESG funds continued to have money at risk that they lost in Russia Graph from a paper by Baruch Lev et al
